source:
pablo mandado and ilze zebolde have no plans , no agenda , no cause to fight for and they are certainly in no hurry -- the couple simply has a dream to ` discover different parts of this planet a pedal at a time . '
and , after quitting their restaurant jobs in manchester , the intrepid cyclists are doing it as cheaply as they possibly can .
spanish pablo , 27 , and latvian ilze , 31 , who met in riga in 2011 , are off to a flying start as they approach their first year of their open-ended odyssey on the road .
in 356 days so far they 've covered almost 7,000 miles ( 11,131.92 km by their measurements ) and been through 16 countries .
ilze zebolde , 31 , takes in her surrounds as she and pablo mandado take a break in their cycle journey around the world
pablo , 27 , and ilze , 31 , stop for a picture in bosnia , one of the 16 countries they 've been through since leaving london last year
latvian ilze sets up camp , the most common means of accommodation for her and pablo , on the stunning lake bled in slovenia
ilze points at the winding road that she and pablo had climb in spain 's sierra nevada with their 130 kg of gear ( including bicycles )
with no plans or agenda , ilze and pablo are happy to stop and take in stunning views , such as this from a roadside in the french alps
in that time they have been astonishingly living on less than three euros each a day , or by their meticulous calculations 10 euro cents per kilometre .
they keep costs down by relying on free accommodation , along with not needing a budget for transport -- their legs have that covered .
usually they pitch a tent under the stars and camp ( 161 nights of the 256 ) but also use hosting websites such as couchsurfing ( 66 nights ) and warmshowers ( 44 nights ) .
sometimes , they get a good night 's sleep courtesy of the kindness of strangers .
showers are ` sometimes daily , sometimes weekly , ' admits pablo .
this leaves food as their only major expense , and that takes up just 2.74 euros each per day of their 2.99 total outlay .
ilze often stars in their images with pablo the designated photographer , but she does n't seem to mind after another hill climb
pablo gives up his camera for a moment , though , as latvian ilze captures her spanish boyfriend taking a rest on the road
while they often pitch their tent in stunning settings , this pedestrian tunnel during their journey through turkey is n't one of them
rolling green hills and a shimmering lake greeted the duo in the alps as their open-ended odyssey continued
when asked on their blog , thecrazytravel , how they can possibly live like this , pablo answered simply .
` pasta , bread , rice , eggs , milk , seasonal fruits and vegetables .
often we get invited for a meal , or for some free veggies or fruits , ' he said .
` we pick up wild fruits occasionally as well , and dumpster diving was an option in western countries where half of the food production end up in the bin . '
pablo and ilze started in london before heading south-east and working their way through france , first down the west coast and then the south after a loop through spain and portugal .
pedal power then took them through the north of italy , slovenia , croatia , bosnia and herzegovina , montenegro , albania , macedonia , greece and into turkey .
ilze walks with her bike while pablo trails behind to capture a snowy landscape in turkey , which they traversed the entire north of
pablo and ilze 's tent in a field in bosnia - this is their usual means of accommodation although they often use hosting websites
pabo and ilze take a break in an italian mountain town as they work their way from france towards eastern europe
pablo rides along the waterside in thessaloniki , greece , one of more than 222 stops they 've made in their journey so far
all landscapes and settings are greeting pablo and ilze , including moody forests in france as they rode along both coasts
ilze rides into the clouds as pedal power takes her and pablo through eastern europe and towards asia , their next continent
the view from pablo and ilze 's tent as they awake to another day in the saddle as they live out their dream
pablo shows off the huge amount of gear he and ilze need to carry as they work their way around the world
` cycling over the bridge at the border between greece and turkey was symbolic , ' pablo says .
` riding away from europe , finally crossing into a different continent .
finally going further away and into the unknown . '
they traversed the entire northern coast of turkey , before riding through georgia and their latest destination , armenia , and they plan to ` continue into asia , across the pacific with the idea to cycle all the length of the american continent . '
` we are going to be on the road for the following years , ' they say .
summary: Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish and Latvian couple, have embarked on a cycling journey around the world with no specific plans or agenda. They started their odyssey in London and have covered approximately 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) in 356 days, passing through 16 countries. They live frugally, spending less than three euros each per day, and rely on free accommodation, such as camping, couchsurfing, and warmshowers, to keep costs down. Their primary expense is food, which takes up about 2.74 euros each per day. They document their journey on their blog, thecrazytravel, and share tips on how they manage to live so inexpensively, such as relying on wild fruits, dumpster diving, and accepting invitations for meals. They plan to continue their journey through Asia, across the Pacific, and eventually cycle the length of the American continent.

summary:
Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a couple from Riga, Latvia and Spain respectively, embarked on a year-long cycling journey around the world in 2011. They quit their jobs in Manchester, UK, and started their adventure with no plans, agenda, or cause to fight for. They aim to discover different parts of the planet, one pedal at a time.

The couple, aged 27 and 31, have been traveling through 16 countries, covering almost 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) so far. They live on less than three euros each per day, or 10 euro cents per kilometer, by relying on free accommodation and not needing a budget for transport. They camp under the stars for 161 nights and use hosting websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers for the remaining nights.

Their diet mainly consists of pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal fruits, and vegetables, with occasional free meals, wild fruits, and even dumpster

summary:
Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Pablo Mandado (27, Spanish) and Ilze Zebolde (31, Latvian) are a couple cycling around the world with no specific plans or agenda. They quit their jobs in Manchester and have been on the road for 356 days, covering almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries. They live on less than 3 euros each per day, mainly camping or using free accommodation services. Their journey started in London and has taken them through Western Europe, the Balkans, and into Turkey. They plan to continue into Asia and eventually cycle the length of the American continent. The couple's goal is simply to "discover different parts of this planet a pedal at a time" and they expect to be on the road for several years.

summary: Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish-Latvian couple, embarked on a cycling journey around the world with no set plans or agenda. They quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester and have been travelling for almost a year, covering 7,000 miles and 16 countries. They live frugally, spending less than €3 per day, relying on free accommodation, camping, and hospitality networks. Their journey has taken them through Europe and Turkey, with plans to continue into Asia and eventually cycle the length of the American continent.

summary: Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a couple from Spain and Latvia respectively, embarked on a dream to explore the world by bicycle without any specific plans or agenda. After leaving their jobs in Manchester, they began their journey, covering nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries in 356 days. They travel extremely frugally, living on less than three euros per person per day, primarily by camping and using hosting websites for accommodation. Their diet consists mainly of simple foods and occasional free meals from locals. The couple plans to continue their journey into Asia and eventually cycle across the Americas.

summary:
Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Pablo Mandado (27) and Ilze Zebolde (31) are a couple on an open-ended cycling journey around the world. They met in 2011 and quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to embark on their adventure. In 356 days, they have covered almost 7,000 miles, visiting 16 countries, and have been living on less than €3 per day. They rely on free accommodation, camping, and hosting websites, and their only major expense is food, which costs around €2.74 per day. They plan to continue cycling through Asia, across the Pacific, and into the Americas, with no set agenda or deadline.

source:
pablo mandado and ilze zebolde have no plans , no agenda , no cause to fight for and they are certainly in no hurry -- the couple simply has a dream to ` discover different parts of this planet a pedal at a time . '
and , after quitting their restaurant jobs in manchester , the intrepid cyclists are doing it as cheaply as they possibly can .
spanish pablo , 27 , and latvian ilze , 31 , who met in riga in 2011 , are off to a flying start as they approach their first year of their open-ended odyssey on the road .
in 356 days so far they 've covered almost 7,000 miles ( 11,131.92 km by their measurements ) and been through 16 countries .
ilze zebolde , 31 , takes in her surrounds as she and pablo mandado take a break in their cycle journey around the world
pablo , 27 , and ilze , 31 , stop for a picture in bosnia , one of the 16 countries they 've been through since leaving london last year
latvian ilze sets up camp , the most common means of accommodation for her and pablo , on the stunning lake bled in slovenia
ilze points at the winding road that she and pablo had climb in spain 's sierra nevada with their 130 kg of gear ( including bicycles )
with no plans or agenda , ilze and pablo are happy to stop and take in stunning views , such as this from a roadside in the french alps
in that time they have been astonishingly living on less than three euros each a day , or by their meticulous calculations 10 euro cents per kilometre .
they keep costs down by relying on free accommodation , along with not needing a budget for transport -- their legs have that covered .
usually they pitch a tent under the stars and camp ( 161 nights of the 256 ) but also use hosting websites such as couchsurfing ( 66 nights ) and warmshowers ( 44 nights ) .
sometimes , they get a good night 's sleep courtesy of the kindness of strangers .
showers are ` sometimes daily , sometimes weekly , ' admits pablo .
this leaves food as their only major expense , and that takes up just 2.74 euros each per day of their 2.99 total outlay .
ilze often stars in their images with pablo the designated photographer , but she does n't seem to mind after another hill climb
pablo gives up his camera for a moment , though , as latvian ilze captures her spanish boyfriend taking a rest on the road
while they often pitch their tent in stunning settings , this pedestrian tunnel during their journey through turkey is n't one of them
rolling green hills and a shimmering lake greeted the duo in the alps as their open-ended odyssey continued
when asked on their blog , thecrazytravel , how they can possibly live like this , pablo answered simply .
` pasta , bread , rice , eggs , milk , seasonal fruits and vegetables .
often we get invited for a meal , or for some free veggies or fruits , ' he said .
` we pick up wild fruits occasionally as well , and dumpster diving was an option in western countries where half of the food production end up in the bin . '
pablo and ilze started in london before heading south-east and working their way through france , first down the west coast and then the south after a loop through spain and portugal .
pedal power then took them through the north of italy , slovenia , croatia , bosnia and herzegovina , montenegro , albania , macedonia , greece and into turkey .
ilze walks with her bike while pablo trails behind to capture a snowy landscape in turkey , which they traversed the entire north of
pablo and ilze 's tent in a field in bosnia - this is their usual means of accommodation although they often use hosting websites
pabo and ilze take a break in an italian mountain town as they work their way from france towards eastern europe
pablo rides along the waterside in thessaloniki , greece , one of more than 222 stops they 've made in their journey so far
all landscapes and settings are greeting pablo and ilze , including moody forests in france as they rode along both coasts
ilze rides into the clouds as pedal power takes her and pablo through eastern europe and towards asia , their next continent
the view from pablo and ilze 's tent as they awake to another day in the saddle as they live out their dream
pablo shows off the huge amount of gear he and ilze need to carry as they work their way around the world
` cycling over the bridge at the border between greece and turkey was symbolic , ' pablo says .
` riding away from europe , finally crossing into a different continent .
finally going further away and into the unknown . '
they traversed the entire northern coast of turkey , before riding through georgia and their latest destination , armenia , and they plan to ` continue into asia , across the pacific with the idea to cycle all the length of the american continent . '
` we are going to be on the road for the following years , ' they say .
summary:
Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information:

Pablo Mandado (27) and Ilze Zebolde (31) are a couple who have embarked on an open-ended cycling journey around the world with no plans or agenda. They started in London and have covered almost 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) through 16 countries in 356 days. They live on a tight budget of less than 3 euros each per day, achieved by relying on free accommodation, camping, and cooking simple meals. They use hosting websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers, and sometimes receive food and hospitality from strangers. Their journey has taken them through Western and Eastern Europe, and they plan to continue into Asia, across the Pacific, and eventually cycle the length of the American continent. They expect to be on the road for several years.

summary: Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are a couple who quit their jobs in Manchester to travel the world by bicycle. They have no set plans or agenda, and they are living on a budget of less than three euros per day. They rely on free accommodation, such as camping, couchsurfing, and warmshowers, and they eat a simple diet of pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal fruits, and vegetables. They have already traveled through 16 countries, covering almost 7,000 miles, and they plan to continue their journey through Asia, across the Pacific, and down the length of the American continent.

summary: Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are a couple who have quit their jobs and embarked on a cycling journey around the world. They have no specific plans or agenda, and their goal is to explore different parts of the planet at their own pace. They have been on the road for almost a year and have covered almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries. They live on a budget of less than three euros each per day, mainly spending on food. They rely on free accommodation, such as camping and hosting websites, to keep costs down. Their next destination is Asia, and they plan to continue cycling across the Pacific and through the entire length of the American continent. They anticipate being on the road for several more years.

summary: Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a couple from Spain and Latvia respectively, quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to embark on an open-ended cycling journey around the world. They have no specific plans or agenda and aim to explore different parts of the planet one pedal at a time. In their first year, they have cycled almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries, living on less than three euros each per day. They keep costs low by camping, using hosting websites, and occasionally relying on the kindness of strangers. Their journey started in London and has taken them through various European countries, and they plan to continue into Asia and eventually across the American continent.
